awd_titl_txt: Faculty Research and Education Development Program
awd_abstract_narration: This project addresses the challenge of increasing diversity in the biological science academic workforce as well as amongst the recipients of grants from national agencies. The Faculty Research and Education Development Program to be implemented in this project focuses on promoting the competitive grant-writing skills of junior faculty at Minority Serving Institutions by matching junior faculty with experienced mentors who are successful senior faculty at research-intensive institutions. The year-long structured mentoring process will focus on the preparation and submission of a grant proposal. In addition to regular (at least monthly) communication between junior faculty and mentors, the program will include 1) Career Development Workshops for junior faculty and mentors, to be held each year 2) reciprocal visits by junior faculty and their mentors to each other's institution, at which they will present a seminar 3) meetings for junior faculty and mentors at the Annual Conference in December of the American Society for Cell Biology. A curated publicly accessible and searchable website will be developed to disseminate results of this program and to serve as a resource for junior faculty and mentors throughout the US. Summative and formative evaluation will be performed by a professional evaluation consultant. Broader Impacts: The goal of this project is to promote the skills in research and education of junior faculty at Minority Serving Institutions, and thereby to improve the educational environment for the undergraduates whom they teach and mentor. Web-based dissemination of the results of this program will make this model accessible to others, and will provide a resource for young scientists to assist them in their professional advancement.

por.por_cntn:
The Faculty Research and Education (FRED) Program is a year-long structured mentorship program run by the Minorities Affairs Committee (MAC) of the American Society for Cell Biology (ASCB) to assist young faculty and postdoctoral fellows in preparing their first nationally funded research or educational grant to support their activities. This program has a target audience of young scientists who are from groups of Persons Excluded because of Ethnicity or Race (PEERS) from scientific careers and faculty at Minority-Serving Institutions (MSI), whose receipt of these grants has been below the success rate for the general population, and whose grant funding is essential for their retention, promotion and professional success at institutions of higher learning. In this program each Mentee is matched with a senior faculty Mentor at another university with funded programs related to the focus of the Mentee"s grant application. The program begins with a 3-day Mentorship Workshop held in the summer at which Mentees initially present their draft Specific Aims for their grant, followed by talks and discussion groups on grant opportunities (NSF, NIH and others), grant preparation and review, and professional development, and with Mentee-Mentor pairs working together to improve the individual Specific Aims. At the end of the Workshop, each Mentee presents and discusses the revised Specific Aims. Based on formative evaluation of the early workshops, a fourth day has been added which is a presentation by Grant Writers on how to succeed in grant proposals submitted to the NIH and NSF.

For the following year each Mentee-Mentor pair works together to prepare the grant, including at least monthly exchange of drafts and remote meetings. During that year, each Mentor visits the Mentee at their institution, to present a seminar on their research to students and faculty and to directly observe the Mentee?s facilities and meet their staff, trainees, colleagues and supervisors. Also, each Mentee visits the Mentor at their institution, to present a seminar and become familiar with the personnel and resources available there. These visits provide further in-depth interaction between the Mentee and Mentor, and promote interaction of their two institutions. This interaction may result in various synergies, including presenting opportunities for inter-institutional collaboration, sharing of technology, offering training opportunities to students, etc.

Each Mentee is expected to have a near-final draft proposal prepared for submission by November, which is submitted to the FRED Program for review. At the December Annual Meeting of the ASCB, a 4-hour Mock Review Panel (study section) is held, which is attended by all Mentees and Mentors, as well as by FRED alumni and members of the MAC. Each grant receives 3 written reviews, and all are presented to the group (which includes all Mentees and Mentors).  The 3 reviews include one by a Mentee, one by a Mentor (not the one who worked with the submitting Mentee), and one by another expert, either a MAC member, or former Mentee or Mentor FRED participant. Each application is reviewed according to the reviewer instructions for the agency to which submission is planned (usually NSF or NIH). Since the submitting Mentees are present, all reviewers are encouraged to be critical but polite. Both Mentees and Mentors have found these sessions to be very valuable. Mentees value both the feedback they receive on their proposals, and the opportunity to better understand the review process so they can improve both their grant preparation and reviewer skills.

Among the 45 Mentees who have completed the FRED Program, 29 have received grant funding, for a success rate of 64%. This compares favorably to other programs designed to enhancer funding of junior faculty, and is far above the overall rate of success by applicants to the NSF or NIH.

The results of the FRED Program have been disseminated by multiple publications by the program faculty and FRED alumni.  Alumni have also returned to give talks and lead discussions at the Mentorship Workshop, and several have subsequently served as Mentors to Mentees in subsequent cohorts.

As part of the FRED Program, a Career Development web portal has been incorporated into the ASCB website. This portal provides scientists and trainees at multiple career stages with access to training opportunities and programs hosted by the ASCB (including FRED), along with guidance on how to obtain further information addressing specific needs.
